meeting_annotations.speaker: Arnold Hayer, McGill
meeting_annotations.transcript: and analysis to achieve that because in 3D you need advanced techniques that are not yet accessible to everyone like lattice light sheet light sheet microscopy and and very reliable computational tools for for tracking individual cells in in those in those systems which I think should in principle be technically possible like tracking in 2D is is pretty trivial in 3D it's much much harder but I think it's it could be done given the imaging techniques that we have then in addition to just tracking it would be nice to have additional properties for each one of the cells like signaling activities some reporters about what's what's going on what state they are what differentiation mode they might have and I I think this is this would potentially allow us to learn more about the fundamental properties of of cellular interactions of organ development which and again if they are not going right then you you would enter a disease state.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
meeting_annotations.transcript: So in um so in optical imaging so my field is optical imaging we uh so we our field specializes in uh imaging resolution um and so we are actually very uh like imaging like cells and even subcellular features are very well within our capabilities. Um but in terms of um but in terms of answering the question about how can we see cells as they migrate through actual organisms the reason that gets difficult is our pain point is imaging through scattering tissue which is whenever you get into bigger biology that's what we struggle with. Like MRI CT pet they we're a lot more um limited by that than the other modalities are. That said uh there is there are a few hybrid approaches are coming in. And so at least for small organisms like um you know like zebrafish or maybe uh even a mouse brain where you like take off the skull and you put like a transmission window through it. In these types of uh specific scenarios there are systems where uh you kind of get pseudo optical resolution but with a lot greater uh penetration depth into the scattering tissue. Um and so I wonder if there's a way to track cells at least in that first millimeter or so depth into the scattering tissue and that might be really important for specific applications where maybe the cell you care about isn't going to go through the whole organism it's only is going to be localized to like the surface areas of the brain or of the spinal cord or whatever. Um and so some technology that I'm really excited about in this space uh like are like of course you have the normal very uh popular optical technologies like confocal and light sheet and stuff like that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
meeting_annotations.transcript: But there are also another another uh set of hybrid imaging techniques that are coming out that are not based on just optics that are that use sound for example like photoacoustics.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um where they're trying to excite light and based on the heating of the of the sample like acoustic waves come out and you measure that. And one of the benefits of this is that it's a label free. Um so it's basically the contrast it's well it doesn't have to be label free but it was initially presented as label free where the contrast is coming from um absorption. So of course you can introduce exogenous particles that are absorptive to give higher contrast to specific specific components.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
meeting_annotations.transcript: But um but maybe there's a way like if you have if you know that for cancer you have increased angiogenesis where you have a lot of blood flow. So increased blood flow corresponds to a red shift in your um in your spectra because of how light gets absorbed. So you can image that with uh photoacoustics for example.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I feel like that's also another promising uh technique for this specific situation when you don't when you're not when your question is not about how cells are migrating through the whole large organism but.
